user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of find_boundary:
```c
static int
find_boundary (struct MHD_PostProcessor *pp,
               const char *boundary,
               size_t blen,
               size_t *ioffptr,
               enum PP_State next_state,
               enum PP_State next_dash_state)
{
  char *buf = (char *) &pp[1];
  const char *dash;

  if (pp->buffer_pos < 2 + blen)
  {
    if (pp->buffer_pos == pp->buffer_size)
      pp->state = PP_Error;     /* out of memory */
    /* ++(*ioffptr); */
    return MHD_NO;              /* not enough data */
  }
  if ( (0 != memcmp ("--",
                     buf,
                     2)) ||
       (0 != memcmp (&buf[2],
                     boundary,
                     blen)))
  {
    if (pp->state != PP_Init)
    {
      /* garbage not allowed */
      pp->state = PP_Error;
    }
    else
    {
      /* skip over garbage (RFC 2046, 5.1.1) */
      dash = memchr (buf,
                     '-',
                     pp->buffer_pos);
      if (NULL == dash)
        (*ioffptr) += pp->buffer_pos;         /* skip entire buffer */
      else if (dash == buf)
        (*ioffptr)++;                         /* at least skip one byte */
      else
        (*ioffptr) += (size_t) (dash - buf);  /* skip to first possible boundary */
    }
    return MHD_NO;                            /* expected boundary */
  }
  /* remove boundary from buffer */
  (*ioffptr) += 2 + blen;
  /* next: start with headers */
  pp->skip_rn = RN_Dash;
  pp->state = next_state;
  pp->dash_state = next_dash_state;
  return MHD_YES;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function find_boundary:
const void *buffer
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I only flagged locations that directly invoke functions from <string.h> or the buffer pointer used by those calls. The other code in the function does not call any <string.h> string/memory functions and therefore is not relevant to Rule 21.17. The early check if (pp->buffer_pos < 2 + blen) returns before the memcmp calls, and the remaining statements only adjust offsets, update state variables, or perform simple arithmetic and pointer comparisons; none of those invoke standard string handling functions or perform unbounded memory accesses that would be covered by Rule 21.17. Consequently they do not need further investigation under this rule.
